turn.text: I would think not and the difference being that we will be talking about a statute which I perceive to have been something this court has discussed as a technical violation of the constitution as opposed to what this court talked about in Sibron versus New York being those statutes which themselves trench on Fourth Amendment rights.
The hypothetical case which you have presented would certainly not trench on any Fourth Amendment rights directly in the statute.

We submit that the Detroit ordinance did so by setting up a vague, setting up an ambiguous statute, setting up one that did not have standards and which allowed police officers at mere whim and caprice to make arrest under a speeding statute of course a police officer would have to be able to point to the fact of why specifically the person was going over the speed limit, how he determined that and I think that he would have excellent standards upon which he could base that determination.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The vagueness and over breath don't have anything to do with the Fourth Amendment -- with due process?

turn.speaker: james_c_howarth
turn.label: Mr. James C. Howarth
turn.text: Vagueness and over breath can.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: They have to do with due process.

turn.speaker: james_c_howarth
turn.label: Mr. James C. Howarth
turn.text: They are due process arguments.

The standard however is that since a warrantless arrest depends on the validity of the arrest to determine probable cause when the arrest cannot ever be found to be valid because there are no standards then you have a warrantless arrest which is in itself unreasonable.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: All you are suggesting is that any statute that happen to pick up the standard that Terry announced would be unconstitutionally vague.

turn.speaker: james_c_howarth
turn.label: Mr. James C. Howarth
turn.text: The standard would not deal with the Terry standard as much as would deal with the identification standard which is the, which is the real problem.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You aren't defending the other part then of the Michigan Court of Appeals opinion on vagueness.

turn.speaker: james_c_howarth
turn.label: Mr. James C. Howarth
turn.text: The vagueness dealing with the fact that the --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Standard, no standard.

turn.speaker: james_c_howarth
turn.label: Mr. James C. Howarth
turn.text: The standard dealing with, whether the citizen will know when he must provide identification no I do agree with the Michigan Court of Appeals on that.
It must be --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well that just must means, that just means that the Terry standard is unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: james_c_howarth
turn.label: Mr. James C. Howarth
turn.text: I don't know that the Terry standard gave no recognition to the fact that a citizen must answer questions and I have -- we have no objection with the right of the police officer to ask questions of the citizen, it the question of whether the citizen must be compelled to answer.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I might also ask or say that your 52.4 just says, seems to me that if, if you make a kind of a stop, a 52.3 contemplate so you may pat him down if you have reasonable cause to believe that he is dangerous.
It doesn't say that if he refuses to identify and then you arrest him that you can't make a full search.

turn.speaker: james_c_howarth
turn.label: Mr. James C. Howarth
turn.text: Well, we had interpreted it as being the really the arrest --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I know apparently you do interpret it that way, but that certainly isn't the way the Court of Appeals interpreted it.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
